segments.text: Well, after we'd set this thing up, I went off back to the Admiralty.
And a month or so, I went over to have a look at it.
It was rather like Henry VIII visiting Trinity.
You know, the founder come to visit the thing.
And the people were all quite enthusiastic about it, because they'd otherwise have been fighting in the Battle of the Bulwark.
And it was really, really great fun.
The first time I went over, it was foggy and the Air Force couldn't take us over.
I got on to the operations at Dover and said, look, can you take us over to France?
They said, sure.
And we were actually the first, we went over in a motor torpedo boat, and we were the first vessel into Boulogne after it was liberated, after the Germans got out.
It was interesting to see a place that we were the first people into.
Nothing had been done, just as left by the Germans.
All the port destroyed, everything blown up.

and then we went back to paris and along the roads of course where all the bridges were blown everything was wrecked and then then we worked our way we got into brussels just after it was liberated wonderful with all the rejoicings of the liberation the the capture we were got in just after the capture of the luftwaffe's wine cellar by the second technical air force we did very well there and then we set up
advanced headquarters in Berlin.
We had all kinds of organizations, really great fun, and not very serious, of course.
Well, then when the German war was over, I decided I really didn't want to sit out the Japanese war as well.
So I went back to Cambridge in, I think, the war ended in August.
Yes, beginning of July, I went back to Cambridge.
It obviously wasn't going to be very long.
The last job I did, was it the last?
No, it was just one interesting thing.
It wasn't much to do with oceanography, but the question was raised about a year or 18 months before the end of the war.
The Combined Chiefs of Staff were told to produce a plan for defeating Japan within a year of the defeat of Germany, because it was thought that the British and
public would not stand the war in Japan going on for more than a year after the defeat of Germany, which seemed quite likely.
And everyone got in on this act in one way or another, considering this question.
It involved, first of all, deciding when Germany was going to be defeated, and secondly, deciding on a plan for defeating Japan within a year thereafter.
Well, it was got completely wrong.
It was decided
that Germany would be defeated in the late fall of 44.
In fact, they lasted six months longer, seven months longer.
And it was decided that Japan could not be defeated within a year thereafter.
It couldn't be defeated by the fall of 45.
And they were both wrong.
And it's very interesting, showing with really very experienced, very intelligent people considering these matters, you get it completely wrong.
on the effect of the bombing of Japan.
I underestimated the effects because I didn't believe what the Air Force said.
In Europe, we'd always divided Air Force estimates by pi because they were always over-optimistic.
In Japan, Japan was much more inflammable and they really had done much more damage than the same weight of bombs in Europe.
We discounted the
We also thought it would take longer to develop airfields on the islands when they were captured than it actually did because it involved bulldozing the tops off all the hills to set up airfields.
We discounted the effects of the atom bomb because we didn't believe it were ready in time.
We didn't think the first test would work.
We thought it would all take longer.
And so he said for planning purposes one should not assume it would work.
So it is a very odd thing and interesting.
It's nothing to do with oceanography, but it's interesting how really the best and most careful consideration by the military experts and their civilian advisors arrived at completely wrong answers.
Well, now, we've now reached the end of the war.
But I have a couple of questions I want to ask you before we reach totally upon the end.
When you're working in terms of gravity experiments on submarines,
Was this involved in warfare?
No, not at all.
I didn't think so.
There was no military application at all at the time.
It has certain applications now, but that's nothing to do with what we're talking about now.
There are questions of the trajectories of ballistic missiles.
The calculation of those involves a knowledge of variations of gravity.
But at the time we were doing it, it had no military application.
And when you were in charge of degassing in terms of mines, did you not in turn invent a kind of mine which was much more effective?
Yes.
Where did you hear that?
Oh, I just... Where did you pick that up?
Roger Revelle.
Yes, that's true.
This man, Ben Brown, whom I talked about before as the man who measured gravity in submarines, he stayed in the anti-submarine establishment.
He suffered fools much more gladly than I did.
And he stayed there.
And he and I, between us, I think I originally invented it, and he did some experiments to see whether it was practical.
We invented a pressure mine, which worked when a ship goes over an object on the bottom, there is a reduction of pressure as it goes over.
And we invented a mine which worked this way.
Well, it was decided to be too dangerous for us to use it because
we had no means of sweeping it.
I put a lot of work into developing methods of sweeping with no success and so it was really a very dangerous thing and it was decided not to use it.

It was used, the Germans must have invented it independently, it was used right at the end of the war in the Scheldt Estuary out when they evacuated Holland and it was used extensively by the Americans in the last stages of the Japanese war.
Now when you go back
I don't know whether the American invention was independent.
I think not.
Well, my impression is it was not.
That was a conversation I drew from Ravel.
Well, I think that's only because I told Ravel I thought it was not independent.
Okay.
After you leave and affect the War Office and...
The Admiralty.
The Admiralty, rather, and you go back to Cambridge, you list yourself as a reader in geophysics.
Well, I started off
Yes, that's right.
I went back as a reader.
Reader is the second level.
It's roughly associate professor.
In an English university in those days, there used to be one professor in each subject.
Occasionally in a very large department there'd be two, but there was normally only one professor, and the other people were called mostly lecturers.
Lecturer is the normal grade of an academic.
One reader is a slightly superior grade, and a professor is a very superior person who runs the department.
I never became a professor in Cambridge until the 60s.
I was in my late 50s when I became a professor.
You know, but while I have you listed as a reader in geophysics, I also have you listed working still for the Navy for four years.
Is that erroneous?
That is erroneous.

always i've always been on naval committees after the war advisory committees of one sort or another but i uh did i've never been employed by the navy since the war i left i left in somewhere about june of 45. all right so then you you do indeed go to cambridge i go to cambridge and i become a reader and then we we started up again and i think in retrospect
I was rather incompetent.
I didn't try and expand the thing as rapid as I should.
I didn't try and get money as rapid as I should do.
I think in spite of everything, Rutherford's dislike of collecting money to some extent rubbed off on me.
I wasn't nearly ambitious enough.
And I didn't press the university enough.
And I got a lot of graduate students.
I mean, people wanted to come and work.
I got prestige by the wartime.
There was great interest in seismology.
One of the first things we took up was the use of wartime explosives.
And we had a project that was 6,000 tons of explosive, I think it was, in Heligoland in a cave.
And it was decided that it was dangerous to get it out, and the Navy decided to detonate it.
And I heard about this and decided to organize a large scale seismological operation to observe this explosion.
And we managed to find all kinds of other dumps of surplus explosive and let them off.
I mean, a few hundred tons here and there.
And so in Germany, where it was easy to do anything in Germany, just after the war, of course, we were the heron folk.
We couldn't do anything.
We bloody were light.
And so we went around blowing up bits of Germany and blew up Heligoland.
The first time I met the environmental movement, there were a whole lot of people who said we frightened the birds on Heligoland.
Heligoland was some kind of bird sanctuary.
So we took a cinema film.
of the operation.
And when we let off the 6,000 tons on the island in this cave, all the birds flew off.
They all got up and they circled around for about a quarter of an hour and sat down again.
And that's all that happened.
Well anyway, I had a graduate student looking after this and it was very interesting seeing Germany immediately after the defeat.
You know, the complete collapse of
their view of themselves as the heron folk.
None of them knew what to do or what they wanted to do, and they just waited to be told.
And I remember I had meetings, I went to the Gttingen, where there was a man called Bartels, who was a very well-known German geophysicist, who I'd taken something of his life to.
a supporter of the Nazi party.
When I went to see him, one of the offices still had a picture of Goebbels in it.
And I thought Mr. Bartels, well, that was either a crook or a knave.
And then, he was very nice to me, of course, and very anxious to collaborate in this blowing up of Helga Land.
Of course, to any scientist who had
had a motor car, we fitted it out with tyres in order that they could take instruments around and set them up for us.
So there was a good deal of a head out of us, and also there were certificates, we supplied certificates to people that they went Nazis.
So there was a good deal of enthusiasm working for us.
And we got very good collaboration from them.
A very curious thing happened.
They said, would you like to see the Gauss?
place where Gauss made his magnetic observations.
And I said, yes, I'd very much like to see it.
So we went out with Bartels and his various henchmen, lovely summer day of 45, through the woods.
And there was a little wooden hut where Gauss made his magnetic observations a hundred and something years before.
And I went up, opened the door and go in, and found it was locked.
And they said, oh, the door is locked.
It is locked to Schlosser.
And I said, yeah.
And Schlosser
And they said, no, it gives consciousness.
There was no key.
And so I said, and it's not a rat.
And I said, I wish to see the interior of this building.
And they said, there is no key.
And I said, well, please break the door in.
And I sat down on the doorstep and waited for them to break the door in.
And then I produced a key from his pocket and opened it.
I walked in, completely empty hut, nothing whatever there, except a little table against one wall.
a vase of fresh flowers on it, and a picture of some Nazi tough over it.
They'd made a little shrine there.
And imagine the stupidity of taking me out there on the off chance that I wouldn't smell a rat.
But it's very interesting, you see, there was no question, as soon as I said I wish this door to be broken in, there was no question at all of opposing me in any way.
I didn't say anything, I didn't tell anyone, I just told them I thought they'd better get it removed.
Very odd, indeed.
I went, I don't know whether the stories of this sort are at all relevant to you.
Right, right.
A little later, it must be later the same year, I think, I went over again, and I went, was it Goettingen again?
I'm not sure.
It was some, I've forgotten now where it was exactly, but the Erdenamische Versuchsanstalt of the Luftwaffe were there, the Luftwaffe's research establishment.
No, this was later.
This was a year or so later.
Sorry, this story comes a little later.
I became disenchanted with the department in Cambridge.
The thing that finally tipped it was that I had a typist coming in two afternoons a week.
And I wanted her every afternoon, and the university refused.
Well, I'd explained to them before I came back to Cambridge and became a reader that geophysics was going to be an expensive operation.
And then when they refused to let me have a typist half time, I felt this was not reasonable.
And that afternoon, a man came in who asked me whether I would take a job in Canada as head of the physics department in Canada.
Well, this was the largest physics department in the British Empire and
Obviously a prestigious job with a very good pay, paid $10,000 a year, which is a lot of money in those days.
And so I took this job.
I knew I didn't want it, and I knew I wasn't going to like it.
But I was so annoyed at having been turned down over this typist that I took the job.
And I went out to Canada, my wife and four children.
And my wife took an enormous dislike to Canada and wouldn't stay there.
And I rather wanted to get out too.
I think, in other circumstances, if my wife hadn't disliked it, I'd probably have stayed.
I don't know.
I think I'd probably come down here because I came down, while I was in Canada, I came down here for the summer and was offered the directorship of scripts before Ravel got it.
And I decided against it.
Of course, my wife wanted to get back to England and I wanted to get back to England.
And I went and saw President Sproul and recommended Ravel.
And there was a good deal of opposition to Ravel down here.
And I told him to overrule it and then the locals would settle down and make Ravel directives.
He did.
Well, anyway, so I had this short time in Canada.
And during that time in Canada, I came down here for the summer.
In the summer of 49, I spent down here.
And I got an enormous amount done in this period.
I built an apparatus for measuring heat flow down here, working with Art Maxwell, who's now Deputy Director of Woods Hole, and who was then a graduate student here.
And it's interesting looking back that there was not enough workshop effort to get the machine built.
It wasn't a very complicated thing.
And so I said that Maxwell and I would build it, and we worked in the workshop.
And I spent a good deal of the summer working in the workshop here, making this apparatus, which we just got finished at the end.
We didn't get any measurements with it that summer.
But we got it built, and we showed that it would work, and everything was all right.
And I went home and built another one, and that gave measurements.
And Maxwell built another one here, slightly different, and that worked.
So I did that that summer.
I also wrote a long paper on the Earth's magnetic field, on the westward drift of the Earth's magnetic field.
And I started to think about the origin of the Earth's magnetic field.
I'd started to think about it just before I left England.
I did a lot of work on that while I was in Canada and while I was down here.
And in retrospect, I think this was my most prolific period, the time in Canada and the time down here in the two or three months in the summer of 1948.
And then, in the course of all this, I got offered the job
of Director of the National Physical Laboratory and very foolishly I took that.
It was a lousy job in many ways and the Lord didn't intend me for a civil servant.
And I got along alright.
I got a good deal of my own work done actually and I directed the lab without any major scandal occurring and I think I
cheer the place up a bit.
It was rather a depressing, slow-moving place and I think I got a certain amount done and I became...
I remember thinking one day, what can the director of this place do?
What influence has he got?
There's a large staff, something like 1,500 people.
What can you do as director of the establishment?
And I decided there were only two things you could do.
First of all, you could interview everyone they hired of a scientific kind so as to make sure you did
hire bright people and not merely people who wouldn't be a nuisance.
And so I insisted on interviewing every single scientific officer who came into the place.
And secondly, we have large controlled budgets.
And in effect, I was being given a lump of money.
And so things I thought went doing well, because they weren't being well run, I could starve them of money.
And use the money to reinforce success, so to speak, and not to boost up failure.
And so on the whole, I think I did a certain amount of good to that show.
Well, I stayed in Canada two years, and I stayed six years at the National Physical Lab.
I went there at the beginning of 1951, I think.
And I stayed there till the end of 1955, which is six years.
Let me just get this right.
I came to Canada in March 48, and I left at the end of 49, that's right.
So I went to the National Physical Lab in January 50, and I stayed till December 56, which is six years.
And then I went back to Cambridge.
By this time, this man Brown,
had taken over as head of the department and reader.
He wasn't a professor.
He took over as reader.
And I went back as the bottom man on the totem pole.
I didn't become a reader.
I went back as an assistant director of research, which was more or less the bottom man on the totem pole.
And it was regarded as highly eccentric.
I'd left one of the prestigious scientific jobs of the world to go back as something a little less than a lecturer.
It was extremely successful for me personally.
I could do what I liked.
I could get on with my own work again.
I could have work with graduate students.
I was paid very little by the university, but I made it up by consulting.
I became a consultant to Shell and a consultant to Rio Tinto.
And in the first year, I made a great deal more money than I ever made as director of the National Physical Lab.
So that was extremely satisfactory.
I also had you listed as director of IBM while you were- Yes, well, I tell you, I became a consultant at Shell.
And I was a consultant at Shell for a long while, I mean, until the 60s.
I left the NPL in 56, and I remained a consultant at Shell for six or eight years.
And I then found, I used to go over to Holland about once or two months, once a month.
and talked to the research lab on exploration production there, go round and look at things, and I got all bored with it.
They knew what I'd say, and I knew what they'd say, and I felt I wasn't having much effect.
I think I ought probably to have spent more time on their affairs and been more insistent.
But anyway, I gave them six months' notice to terminate the country.
And I didn't know what I was going to do.
I didn't know what other job I knew I would take up something else with industry.
And suddenly one day I was offered a job as director of IBM in England.
This was a tremendous success.
I enjoyed IBM enormously.
They felt they'd like to have somewhat, most of the board of IBM UK were financiers.
They were bankers from whom people borrowed money, accountants, merchant bankers, this kind of thing.
and a number of employees of the company, and they thought they'd like to have someone different.
And I don't know quite why they selected me, but it just suited me.
Is this the first time you've become involved with computers?
No, I'd been interested in computers all along.
One of the earliest computers was built at the National Physical Lab while I was there.
I knew Jonathan Neumann when I was in Canada.
We'd set up a computing center there with one of the first computers.
I'd been down to see Jonathan Neumann, who was building one of the first ones.
I'd seen something during the war of the cryptographic computers, whose existence has recently been revealed.
So I was deeply interested in computers, and I was practically the only man on the board in anything about them.
It's been suggested that you were in the vanguard of placing computers into British science.
Would you agree with that statement?

certainly I was one of the first people who took them seriously in geophysics I mean computers are used for two things in science one is data analysis if you've got a subject like astronomy or geophysics where there's an enormous amount of information badly contaminated with noise then you need a computer to analyse the data and I was certainly early in this business I did a lot of
the early programming for recording data on board ship and then analyzing it after you got home.
Now, of course, you do the analysis as well at sea because you have the computers at sea.
But at that time, the computers were on land and you brought the data back on paper tape and put it into the computers.
And I did a lot of programming and experimental work on data analysis in oceanography.
This I...
when I got back to Cambridge, I used to visit here in the summer from the late 50s onwards.
And I worked here with Walter Monk and Flicka down the corridor, Flicka Dolma, Flicka Oglebay as it was, on general programs for analyzing data.
So I think I did have substantial influence on the adoption of computers for data analysis in geophysics.
And the other side
of the use of computers in science is their use for analyzing models.
If you have a phenomenon, say an ice age or a tsunami or something of this sort, or the tides, then you have a theory of it.
And your theory is a simplified model of reality.
And you want to predict what this model will say about the observations, about what should happen, and then compare
what actually happens and what the theory gives.
And this is quite a different sort of computing.
It's solving differential equations and things.
And I haven't...
I did some of this in the magnetic field business, the origin of the Earth's magnetic field.
And so that I think on both sides I did something.
I was in that when I was at the National Physical Lab.
I started doing that.
Being director of the lab, I could get as much computer time as I wanted...
The National Physical Lab, though, was not defense-oriented, was it?
No.
Okay, I don't think so.
No, it was industry-oriented.
It was particularly standards.
When did you first become interested in heat flow?
I first became interested in heat flow in the middle 30s.
I remember talking to Jeffries about it.
I was interested...
I think my first interest was how reliable were the few measurements we had.
Wait a minute now, now my first interest, Jeffries talked to me about the shortage of heat flow measurements, there were very few.
I wrote a historical article on the history of heat flow measurement.
What had happened was,
I've become, well, I think to go into the details of Mr. Lee is really rather unnecessary, but Mr. Lee was a graduate student here.
And for reasons that are too complicated to describe, I got him made Secretary of the International Keep Flow Committee when he was about 22 or 23, I suppose.
Enormously energetic man, determined to make his fortune, his fame and fortune.
And one of the things he did was to start to get
a collaborative book written about heat flow from the earth to be published by his international heat flow committee.
And he asked me to write a summarizing chapter.
And I refused to do it on the grounds that I couldn't be bothered to read all the manuscripts he'd got.
And he wrote to me a very fierce letter in which he said he thought this was very unreasonable.
I just must write him an article.
He was clearly one of these people like Dick Field who wouldn't take no for an answer.
So I said I would write him an article on the history of heat flow.
This was intended originally more or less a joke, and I started to write a history of heat flow in the 17th century.
And so I wrote an article on the study of heat flow from the Earth in the 17th century, which is rather surprising.
Boyle was interested in it.
And then I decided to write this more seriously, and I continued it up to the present day.
And I haven't got a copy of this here, I'm afraid.
But anyway, in the middle 30s, I'd become interested in it.
This was in the 50s sometime.
I'd become interested in the thing in the 30s.
Of course, Jeffries had pointed out how few measurements there were.
And I'd put a graduate student onto it in about 36 or 37.
And he was making measurements in England in collaboration with the oil companies who got some boreholes.
And I did some measurements in South Africa.
And so I then became, I became interested in the whole question, how do you measure heat flow?
How, what sources of uncertainty are there?
I became interested in the effect of the topography of the earth and distorting the heat flow and so on.
And I then also became interested just before the war in the possibility of making measurements at sea.
And at that time, war was on us.
I didn't get anything done before the war.
Then, after the war, I tried to get Maurice Ewing interested.
And Morris Ewing had his own problems and couldn't give me ship time.
And eventually Roger Revelle offered me ship time.
But then when I got down here, he wouldn't give me any workshop time.
I think very foolishly.
And so Art Maxwell and I went into the workshop here and started to build the equipment.
And I was very surprised that the workshop manager, the head mechanic, wouldn't let us into the store.
And I thought this was very odd.
It turned out afterwards that there was a racket going on.
He was buying stores and running a shop in town and selling them again.
And, of course, we were very liable to discover this racket, that he was taking things away in the evening, because we were staying much later than he was.
So it must have been a grave embarrassment to him.
And shortly after we left, this all came out.
